<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">Please cite this paper as: Knowledge of swine flu among </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">Health Care workers and General Population of Haryana </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">India during 2009 pandemic. Kumar N, Sood S, Singh M, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">Kumar M, Makkar B, Singh M. AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">Doi 10.4066/AMJ.2010.314 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="16">Corresponding Author: </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">Dr. Naresh Kumar </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">11 J / 3 Medical Campus </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">PGIMS, Rohtak, Haryana </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20">PIN 124001 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">Email: drnaresh10@gmail.com </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:12; color:#993300; bold; line_num="22">Abstract </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="23">Background </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">A swine flu pandemic hit the world and India was no </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="25">exception. Many deaths were reported in metropolitan </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">cities. Knowledge about the infection is an important </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">element of control of the infection. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="28">Method </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">This cross sectional survey was conducted at a tertiary care </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">centre hospital where the patients are referred from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">different parts of Haryana accompanied by relatives </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">therefore it was regarded as a potentially high-risk area for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">the spread of Influenza A (H1N1) and chosen to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">knowledge, attitude and practice in relation to swine flu. A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="35">self administered questionnaire involved 42 hospital staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">members (HS) and 358 general public (GP) accompanying </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">the patients from  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;1st September 2009 to 15th October 2009. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="38">Results </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">Out of all respondents only 25% had heard of swine flu </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="40">before and out of which 65% HS & 37% GP knew more than </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">three correct symptoms. There were 86% respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">(HS=95% & GP=80%) who thought that touching the eyes, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">nose or mouth without washing hands can spread the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">disease. Altogether 80% respondents thought that the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">disease was controllable while, nearly 92% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">knew about the nearest swine flu control or testing centre. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">Among all hardly 10% had attended some type of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">awareness program for swine flu control and 62% were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">taking precautions against the spread of swine flu. Nearly </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">70% of respondents thought that masks prevent the disease </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">while about 98% washed their hands before having meal. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">Nearly 72% of this knowledge was from television and 20% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">from newspapers. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="54">Conclusion </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">In the present study group many of the respondents didn’t </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">know about swine flu. Most were from the general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">population. We recommend a public health campaign in </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">Haryana. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="59">Key Words </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="60">Swine flu, knowledge, attitude, practices, medical staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="61">Background </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">Swine Flu pandemic detected in April 2009 contained </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">a combination of genes from swine, avian (bird), and human </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">influenza viruses.1,2 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">The outbreak began in Mexico, with </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">evidence that there had been an ongoing epidemic for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">months before it was officially recognized as such.3 The </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">virus continued to spread globally, and the World Health </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">Organization (WHO) in June declared the outbreak to be a </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">pandemic4 and raised a strong signal that a pandemic is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">imminent and that the time to finalize the organization, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">communication and implementation of the planned </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">mitigation measures is short. As of 6 August 2009, the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">World Health Organization reported 1,77,457 laboratory </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">confirmed cases of influenza A/H1N1 and 1,462 deaths.5 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">India was no exception and many deaths (138 as of 9 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">September 2009) were reported in metropolitan cities such </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="78">as Mumbai, Pune and Bangalore.6 Given the seriousness of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="79">the situation and lack of any specific vaccine against </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="80">Influenza A (H1N1), mitigation measures in the India have so </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:12; color:#000000; line_num="81">614 </Line>
page number : 2 ------------------------ 

<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:9; color:#000000; line_num="1">Australasian Medical Journal AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="2">far focused on identifying, treating, and isolating people </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="3">who have the disease and educating the public about the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="4">steps that individuals can take to reduce the risk of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="5">transmission. These recommendations include using tissues </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="6">when sneezing, washing hands regularly with soap and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="7">water.7 The media, including both televised and written </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="8">media, and to a lesser extent the radio and the internet, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="9">where free uncensored writing and U-tube postings take </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="10">place had led to inappropriate behaviour by the public such </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">as; refusal to comply with precautionary measures, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">including wearing a mask or accepting a vaccination; </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">avoidance of certain activities including visiting the hospital </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">due to fear of healthcare facilities as a venue for acquiring </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">the infection.8-10 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="16">There was a large need for the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">dissemination of accurate information to overcome the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">misinformed dialogue taking place on TV, newspapers and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">internet. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20"> style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;11 During a pandemic, public health agencies can </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">play critical roles in controlling the spread of disease.12 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="22">Therefore the present study was designed to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="23">knowledge, attitude and practice during swine flu epidemic </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">among the medical staff and the general population. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="25">Method </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">This cross sectional survey was conducted at a tertiary care </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">centre hospital where the patients are referred from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="28">different parts of Haryana accompanied by relatives </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">therefore it was regarded as a potentially high-risk area for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">the spread of Influenza A (H1N1) and chosen to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">knowledge, attitude and practice in relation to swine flu. A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">self administered questionnaire involved 42 hospital staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">members (HS) and 358 general public (GP) accompanying </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">the patients from  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;1st September 2009 to 15th October 2009. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="35">Results </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">A total of 400 subjects (Hospital staff= 42 & general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">population= 358) with mean ± SD age group of 31.42 ± </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="38">10.65 years (Range= 12  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000;– 62 years) participated in the study. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">There were 214 males and 186 females. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="40">Knowledge response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">Out of all respondents only 25% (100) had heard of swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">flu before. Out of these 25% (100) respondents, 95% (38) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">hospital staff (HS) and 100% (60) of general population (GP) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">knew about symptoms of swine flu. Sixty five percent of HS </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">and thirty seven percent of GP knew more than three </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">correct symptoms. 65% of HS and 74% of GP thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">this was a disease of children and elderly patients, while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">35% of HS and 22% of GP thought that adults with co </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">morbidities like asthma and diabetes were at a greater risk </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">and only 2% of GP didn’t know about it. There were 95% HS </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">and 86% general people who thought that touching of eyes, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">nose or mouth without washing hands can spread the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">disease while only 5% HS and 10% GP thought that it was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="54">partially true and 6.66 % of GP didn’t know the answer. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">Altogether, 80% of HS and GP thought that the disease was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">controllable while, 15% of HS and 10% of GP thought that it </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">was not and 10% of GP didn’t know the answer. Nearly 95% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">of HS and 92% of GP knew about the nearest swine flu </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="59">control or testing centre and half of HS were aware of the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="60">Practice response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="61">About 98% respondents (HS=100% & GP=96.67%) wash </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">their hands before having meals. 62% (HS=55% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">GP=66.67%) were definitely taking precautions against the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">spread of swine flu while 14% (HS=20% & GP=10%) were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">taking partial precautions, while 24% (HS=25% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">GP=23.33%) were not taking any precautions. Disposal of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">mask was done by throwing them into the dustbin by 34% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">(HS=60% & GP=16.67%) while, disposal by burning was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">done by 20% (HS=30% & GP=13.33%). However, 46% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">(HS=10% & GP=70%) did not know how to dispose masks. Of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">the respondents 46% (HS=80% & GP=23.33%) thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">it was not safe to reuse the mask more than once and 3.33% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">general population thought that this was partially true while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">40% respondents (HS=10% & P=60%) did not knew the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">answer and 12% (HS= 10% & GP=13.33%) answered that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">mask can be reused. There were 94% (HS=85% & GP=100%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">of respondents who thought that if they had developed the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="78">symptoms of swine flu then they would have contacted the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="79">swine flu centre immediately for diagnosis while only 10% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="80">hospital staff thought that they would have taken the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="81">proper precautions to prevent the spread of disease and 5% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="82">of HS thought that they would have done both. Nearly 94% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="83">respondents (HS=100% & GP=90%) used tissue or </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="84">handkerchief while sneezing or coughing and when the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="85">respondents had to visit some swine flu infected area then </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="86">40% (HS= 60% & GP=26.67%) wash their hands with soap </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="87">and water more frequently and thoroughly while 40% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="88">(HS=30% & GP=46.67%) respondents avoid contact with the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="89">people who appeared sick and 30% (HS=40% & GP=23.33%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="90">followed the both precautions. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="91">Discussion </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="92">In spite of the increase in the number of Influenza A (H1N1) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="93">cases as well as the response of the WHO by raising its </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="94">pandemic alert status to phase 6 and extensive media </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="95">coverage, public responses to Influenza A (H1N1) were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="96">muted. In practice, convincing the public that the threat is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="97">real is often a more pressing task for public health agencies </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="98">than providing reassurance.  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;7 Many reports have examined </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="99">the various levels of knowledge about infectious agents and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="100">public behavior in relation to these infections; such studies </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="101">have primarily focused on the SARS and avian influenza </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="102">outbreaks.8,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;13 Other studies have been recently published </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="103">specifically on behavioral and attitudinal responses to </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="104">pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Influenza.10,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;14-16 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:12; color:#000000; line_num="105">615 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="106">second wave of swine flu epidemic but 72% of GP were not </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="107">aware of it. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="108">Attitude response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="109">Only 10% of HS and GP had attended some type of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="110">awareness program for swine flu control. Nearly 65% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="111">(HS=65% & GP=66.67%) did not avoid public gatherings like </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="112">parties and group meetings of the fear of swine flu while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="113">rest 35% avoid such meetings. Nearly 70% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="114">(HS=65% & GP=73.33%) definitely thought that mask </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="115">prevents the disease and 20% (HS=30% & GP=13.33%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="116">thought that it was partially true and only 10% (HS=5% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="117">GP=13.33%) didn’t know the  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000;answer. </Line>
page number : 3 ------------------------ 

<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:9; color:#000000; line_num="1">Australasian Medical Journal AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="2">In our study nearly 75% of the respondents had never heard </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="3">of the swine flu before out of which 99.33% were of general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="4">population and only 0.67% were of medical staff. Out of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="5">which 52% knew more than three symptoms. In another </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="6">study by Kamate et al 83% of subjects had heard about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="7">swine flu.17 In another study 44% of national sample of adult </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="8">Australians reported having knowledge of the term </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="9">pandemic influenza,18 a finding similar to that of a study </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="10">conducted in the USA in 2006 in which 41% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">had previously heard of this term.7 So here we conclude </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">that our respondents have far less knowledge about swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">flu than the above studies and the reason may be lack of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">public health communications. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">In our study nearly 72 % of respondents learned about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="16">swine flu from television while about 20% came to know </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">about the disease in newspapers and only 8% through word </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">of mouth. Similarly in an another study the majority (84.2%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">of the participants received their information about swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20">flu from the television; 51.1% received information from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">written media such as newspapers and magazines, while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="22">48.2% received information from the internet.19 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="23">In a recent review of behavioural responses to influenza </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">pandemics in the 20th century,20 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="25">the only two measures </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">that had strong support by scientific literature to lessen the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">spread of the diseases were hand hygiene and respiratory </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="28">etiquette. School closure and screening of travellers had </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">legal and ethical consequences when implemented. While </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">the other four measures, including isolation and wearing of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">a surgical mask or an N95 mask, had cost effectiveness </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">concerns and would be difficult to implement over long </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">periods of time.21,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;22 Maximum of the respondents (86%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">thought that swine flu can be spread by poor hygiene like </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="35">touching eyes, nose or mouth without washing their hands </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">and actually 98% of respondents washed their hands before </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">meals while nearly 94% use tissue or handkerchief while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="38">coughing or sneezing. In another study nearly, one-third </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">reported avoiding touching their eyes, nose, or mouth </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="40">(36.6%) and covering their nose and mouth with a tissue </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">when coughing or sneezing (38.0%). However, only one- </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">fourth of participants reported throwing the tissue in the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">trash after use (26.9%) and avoiding normal activities if they </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">have flulike symptoms (25.7%).17 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">It is important to know what proportion of the population is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">concerned about contracting a disease since those who are </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">concerned would be expected to take more precautions. In </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">a telephone-assisted survey of 2,081 adults above the age </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">of 16 years, the New South Wales Department of Health </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">found that only 48.3% of those interviewed were willing to </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">comply with precautionary measures.23,24 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">reduced the use of public transportation; 74.3% had not </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">taken any time off work; However, more than half the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="54">respondents (52.6%; 416/791) avoided crowded places and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">54.6% washed their hands with soap and water more often </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">than usual, and 63.6% were not overtly worried about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">cleaning or disinfecting things that they might touch.17 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">Nearly 70% of the respondents believed that using masks </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="59">definitely prevents swine flu while 20% were not sure </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="60">whether masks could prevent from the disease and 10% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="61">didn’t knew the answer. Nearly 34% disposed the used </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">mask by throwing it into dustbin, 20% disposed them by </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">burning and 46% did not know how to dispose the masks. In </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">another study the willingness to wear a mask during a </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">pandemic was surprisingly high (95%), particularly as this is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">not common practice in Australia.18 Use of masks by the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">general public in China, Hong Kong, Special Administrative </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">Region, during the 2003 severe acute respiratory syndrome </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">(SARS) outbreak was below this level.22 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">Eighty percent of our respondents definitely thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">the disease was controllable while 10% thought that this </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">was partially true while in an another study two percent of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">the respondents were of the opinion that Influenza A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">(H1N1) would not affect their health; 36.4% feared that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">they would be somewhat affected; 34.5% believed that they </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">would be seriously affected; and 27.1% had no idea about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">the effect of Influenza A (H1N1) on their health.17 </Line>

<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="38"> style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000;18. Eastwood K, Durrheim D, Francis JL, d’Espaignet ET, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">Duncan S, Islam F et al. Knowledge about </Line>

<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:9; color:#000000; line_num="1">Australasian Medical Journal AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:14.04; color:#FFFFFF; bold; line_num="2">Knowledge of Swine Flu among Health Care Workers and General Population of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:14.04; color:#FFFFFF; bold; line_num="3">Haryana, India during 2009 Pandemic </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; bold; line_num="4">Naresh Kumar  style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:8.04; color:#FFFFFF; bold;1 Sushma Sood1 Manjeet Singh1 Mukesh Kumar2 Beena Makkar1 Manusha </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; bold; line_num="5">Singh3 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; line_num="6">1. Department of Physiology, Pt B.D. Sharma PGIMS, Rohtak, Haryana. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; line_num="7">2. Department of Pharmacy Practice, Kasturba Medical College Manipal University, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; line_num="8">Mangalore, Karnataka. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:12; color:#FFFFFF; line_num="9">3. Medical Student, Pt B.D. Sharma PGIMS, Rohtak, Haryana. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:12; color:#993300; bold; line_num="10">RESEARCH </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">Please cite this paper as: Knowledge of swine flu among </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">Health Care workers and General Population of Haryana </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">India during 2009 pandemic. Kumar N, Sood S, Singh M, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">Kumar M, Makkar B, Singh M. AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">Doi 10.4066/AMJ.2010.314 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="16">Corresponding Author: </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">Dr. Naresh Kumar </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">11 J / 3 Medical Campus </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">PGIMS, Rohtak, Haryana </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20">PIN 124001 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">Email: drnaresh10@gmail.com </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:12; color:#993300; bold; line_num="22">Abstract </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="23">Background </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">A swine flu pandemic hit the world and India was no </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="25">exception. Many deaths were reported in metropolitan </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">cities. Knowledge about the infection is an important </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">element of control of the infection. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="28">Method </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">This cross sectional survey was conducted at a tertiary care </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">centre hospital where the patients are referred from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">different parts of Haryana accompanied by relatives </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">therefore it was regarded as a potentially high-risk area for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">the spread of Influenza A (H1N1) and chosen to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">knowledge, attitude and practice in relation to swine flu. A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="35">self administered questionnaire involved 42 hospital staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">members (HS) and 358 general public (GP) accompanying </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">the patients from  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;1st September 2009 to 15th October 2009. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="38">Results </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">Out of all respondents only 25% had heard of swine flu </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="40">before and out of which 65% HS & 37% GP knew more than </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">three correct symptoms. There were 86% respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">(HS=95% & GP=80%) who thought that touching the eyes, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">nose or mouth without washing hands can spread the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">disease. Altogether 80% respondents thought that the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">disease was controllable while, nearly 92% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">knew about the nearest swine flu control or testing centre. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">Among all hardly 10% had attended some type of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">awareness program for swine flu control and 62% were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">taking precautions against the spread of swine flu. Nearly </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">70% of respondents thought that masks prevent the disease </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">while about 98% washed their hands before having meal. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">Nearly 72% of this knowledge was from television and 20% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">from newspapers. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="54">Conclusion </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">In the present study group many of the respondents didn’t </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">know about swine flu. Most were from the general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">population. We recommend a public health campaign in </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">Haryana. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="59">Key Words </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="60">Swine flu, knowledge, attitude, practices, medical staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="61">Background </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">Swine Flu pandemic detected in April 2009 contained </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">a combination of genes from swine, avian (bird), and human </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">influenza viruses.1,2 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">The outbreak began in Mexico, with </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">evidence that there had been an ongoing epidemic for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">months before it was officially recognized as such.3 The </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">virus continued to spread globally, and the World Health </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">Organization (WHO) in June declared the outbreak to be a </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">pandemic4 and raised a strong signal that a pandemic is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">imminent and that the time to finalize the organization, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">communication and implementation of the planned </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">mitigation measures is short. As of 6 August 2009, the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">World Health Organization reported 1,77,457 laboratory </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">confirmed cases of influenza A/H1N1 and 1,462 deaths.5 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">India was no exception and many deaths (138 as of 9 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">September 2009) were reported in metropolitan cities such </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="78">as Mumbai, Pune and Bangalore.6 Given the seriousness of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="79">the situation and lack of any specific vaccine against </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="80">Influenza A (H1N1), mitigation measures in the India have so </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:12; color:#000000; line_num="81">614 </Line>
page number : 2 ------------------------ 

<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:9; color:#000000; line_num="1">Australasian Medical Journal AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="2">far focused on identifying, treating, and isolating people </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="3">who have the disease and educating the public about the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="4">steps that individuals can take to reduce the risk of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="5">transmission. These recommendations include using tissues </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="6">when sneezing, washing hands regularly with soap and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="7">water.7 The media, including both televised and written </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="8">media, and to a lesser extent the radio and the internet, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="9">where free uncensored writing and U-tube postings take </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="10">place had led to inappropriate behaviour by the public such </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">as; refusal to comply with precautionary measures, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">including wearing a mask or accepting a vaccination; </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">avoidance of certain activities including visiting the hospital </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">due to fear of healthcare facilities as a venue for acquiring </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">the infection.8-10 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="16">There was a large need for the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">dissemination of accurate information to overcome the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">misinformed dialogue taking place on TV, newspapers and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">internet. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20"> style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;11 During a pandemic, public health agencies can </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">play critical roles in controlling the spread of disease.12 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="22">Therefore the present study was designed to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="23">knowledge, attitude and practice during swine flu epidemic </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">among the medical staff and the general population. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="25">Method </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">This cross sectional survey was conducted at a tertiary care </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">centre hospital where the patients are referred from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="28">different parts of Haryana accompanied by relatives </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">therefore it was regarded as a potentially high-risk area for </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">the spread of Influenza A (H1N1) and chosen to assess the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">knowledge, attitude and practice in relation to swine flu. A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">self administered questionnaire involved 42 hospital staff </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">members (HS) and 358 general public (GP) accompanying </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">the patients from  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;1st September 2009 to 15th October 2009. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="35">Results </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">A total of 400 subjects (Hospital staff= 42 & general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">population= 358) with mean ± SD age group of 31.42 ± </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="38">10.65 years (Range= 12  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000;– 62 years) participated in the study. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">There were 214 males and 186 females. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="40">Knowledge response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">Out of all respondents only 25% (100) had heard of swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">flu before. Out of these 25% (100) respondents, 95% (38) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">hospital staff (HS) and 100% (60) of general population (GP) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">knew about symptoms of swine flu. Sixty five percent of HS </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">and thirty seven percent of GP knew more than three </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">correct symptoms. 65% of HS and 74% of GP thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">this was a disease of children and elderly patients, while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">35% of HS and 22% of GP thought that adults with co </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">morbidities like asthma and diabetes were at a greater risk </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">and only 2% of GP didn’t know about it. There were 95% HS </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">and 86% general people who thought that touching of eyes, </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">nose or mouth without washing hands can spread the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">disease while only 5% HS and 10% GP thought that it was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="54">partially true and 6.66 % of GP didn’t know the answer. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">Altogether, 80% of HS and GP thought that the disease was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">controllable while, 15% of HS and 10% of GP thought that it </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">was not and 10% of GP didn’t know the answer. Nearly 95% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">of HS and 92% of GP knew about the nearest swine flu </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="59">control or testing centre and half of HS were aware of the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="60">Practice response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="61">About 98% respondents (HS=100% & GP=96.67%) wash </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">their hands before having meals. 62% (HS=55% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">GP=66.67%) were definitely taking precautions against the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">spread of swine flu while 14% (HS=20% & GP=10%) were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">taking partial precautions, while 24% (HS=25% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">GP=23.33%) were not taking any precautions. Disposal of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">mask was done by throwing them into the dustbin by 34% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">(HS=60% & GP=16.67%) while, disposal by burning was </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">done by 20% (HS=30% & GP=13.33%). However, 46% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">(HS=10% & GP=70%) did not know how to dispose masks. Of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">the respondents 46% (HS=80% & GP=23.33%) thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">it was not safe to reuse the mask more than once and 3.33% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">general population thought that this was partially true while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">40% respondents (HS=10% & P=60%) did not knew the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">answer and 12% (HS= 10% & GP=13.33%) answered that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">mask can be reused. There were 94% (HS=85% & GP=100%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">of respondents who thought that if they had developed the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="78">symptoms of swine flu then they would have contacted the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="79">swine flu centre immediately for diagnosis while only 10% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="80">hospital staff thought that they would have taken the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="81">proper precautions to prevent the spread of disease and 5% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="82">of HS thought that they would have done both. Nearly 94% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="83">respondents (HS=100% & GP=90%) used tissue or </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="84">handkerchief while sneezing or coughing and when the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="85">respondents had to visit some swine flu infected area then </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="86">40% (HS= 60% & GP=26.67%) wash their hands with soap </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="87">and water more frequently and thoroughly while 40% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="88">(HS=30% & GP=46.67%) respondents avoid contact with the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="89">people who appeared sick and 30% (HS=40% & GP=23.33%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="90">followed the both precautions. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#993300; bold; line_num="91">Discussion </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="92">In spite of the increase in the number of Influenza A (H1N1) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="93">cases as well as the response of the WHO by raising its </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="94">pandemic alert status to phase 6 and extensive media </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="95">coverage, public responses to Influenza A (H1N1) were </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="96">muted. In practice, convincing the public that the threat is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="97">real is often a more pressing task for public health agencies </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="98">than providing reassurance.  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;7 Many reports have examined </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="99">the various levels of knowledge about infectious agents and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="100">public behavior in relation to these infections; such studies </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="101">have primarily focused on the SARS and avian influenza </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="102">outbreaks.8,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;13 Other studies have been recently published </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="103">specifically on behavioral and attitudinal responses to </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="104">pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Influenza.10,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;14-16 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:12; color:#000000; line_num="105">615 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="106">second wave of swine flu epidemic but 72% of GP were not </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="107">aware of it. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; bold; line_num="108">Attitude response </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="109">Only 10% of HS and GP had attended some type of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="110">awareness program for swine flu control. Nearly 65% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="111">(HS=65% & GP=66.67%) did not avoid public gatherings like </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="112">parties and group meetings of the fear of swine flu while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="113">rest 35% avoid such meetings. Nearly 70% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="114">(HS=65% & GP=73.33%) definitely thought that mask </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="115">prevents the disease and 20% (HS=30% & GP=13.33%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="116">thought that it was partially true and only 10% (HS=5% & </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="117">GP=13.33%) didn’t know the  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000;answer. </Line>
page number : 3 ------------------------ 

<Line style="font-family:Cambria; font-size:9; color:#000000; line_num="1">Australasian Medical Journal AMJ 2010, 3, 9, 614-617 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="2">In our study nearly 75% of the respondents had never heard </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="3">of the swine flu before out of which 99.33% were of general </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="4">population and only 0.67% were of medical staff. Out of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="5">which 52% knew more than three symptoms. In another </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="6">study by Kamate et al 83% of subjects had heard about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="7">swine flu.17 In another study 44% of national sample of adult </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="8">Australians reported having knowledge of the term </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="9">pandemic influenza,18 a finding similar to that of a study </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="10">conducted in the USA in 2006 in which 41% of respondents </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="11">had previously heard of this term.7 So here we conclude </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="12">that our respondents have far less knowledge about swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="13">flu than the above studies and the reason may be lack of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="14">public health communications. </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="15">In our study nearly 72 % of respondents learned about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="16">swine flu from television while about 20% came to know </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="17">about the disease in newspapers and only 8% through word </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="18">of mouth. Similarly in an another study the majority (84.2%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="19">of the participants received their information about swine </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="20">flu from the television; 51.1% received information from </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="21">written media such as newspapers and magazines, while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="22">48.2% received information from the internet.19 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="23">In a recent review of behavioural responses to influenza </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="24">pandemics in the 20th century,20 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="25">the only two measures </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="26">that had strong support by scientific literature to lessen the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="27">spread of the diseases were hand hygiene and respiratory </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="28">etiquette. School closure and screening of travellers had </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="29">legal and ethical consequences when implemented. While </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="30">the other four measures, including isolation and wearing of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="31">a surgical mask or an N95 mask, had cost effectiveness </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="32">concerns and would be difficult to implement over long </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="33">periods of time.21,  style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:6.48; color:#000000;22 Maximum of the respondents (86%) </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="34">thought that swine flu can be spread by poor hygiene like </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="35">touching eyes, nose or mouth without washing their hands </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="36">and actually 98% of respondents washed their hands before </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="37">meals while nearly 94% use tissue or handkerchief while </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="38">coughing or sneezing. In another study nearly, one-third </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="39">reported avoiding touching their eyes, nose, or mouth </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="40">(36.6%) and covering their nose and mouth with a tissue </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="41">when coughing or sneezing (38.0%). However, only one- </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="42">fourth of participants reported throwing the tissue in the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="43">trash after use (26.9%) and avoiding normal activities if they </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="44">have flulike symptoms (25.7%).17 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="45">It is important to know what proportion of the population is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="46">concerned about contracting a disease since those who are </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="47">concerned would be expected to take more precautions. In </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="48">a telephone-assisted survey of 2,081 adults above the age </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="49">of 16 years, the New South Wales Department of Health </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="50">found that only 48.3% of those interviewed were willing to </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="51">comply with precautionary measures.23,24 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="52">reduced the use of public transportation; 74.3% had not </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="53">taken any time off work; However, more than half the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="54">respondents (52.6%; 416/791) avoided crowded places and </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="55">54.6% washed their hands with soap and water more often </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="56">than usual, and 63.6% were not overtly worried about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="57">cleaning or disinfecting things that they might touch.17 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="58">Nearly 70% of the respondents believed that using masks </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="59">definitely prevents swine flu while 20% were not sure </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="60">whether masks could prevent from the disease and 10% </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="61">didn’t knew the answer. Nearly 34% disposed the used </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="62">mask by throwing it into dustbin, 20% disposed them by </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="63">burning and 46% did not know how to dispose the masks. In </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="64">another study the willingness to wear a mask during a </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="65">pandemic was surprisingly high (95%), particularly as this is </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="66">not common practice in Australia.18 Use of masks by the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="67">general public in China, Hong Kong, Special Administrative </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="68">Region, during the 2003 severe acute respiratory syndrome </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="69">(SARS) outbreak was below this level.22 </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="70">Eighty percent of our respondents definitely thought that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="71">the disease was controllable while 10% thought that this </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="72">was partially true while in an another study two percent of </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="73">the respondents were of the opinion that Influenza A </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="74">(H1N1) would not affect their health; 36.4% feared that </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="75">they would be somewhat affected; 34.5% believed that they </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="76">would be seriously affected; and 27.1% had no idea about </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="77">the effect of Influenza A (H1N1) on their health.17 </Line>

<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="100">In our study </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="101">nearly 66% responded that they did not avoid public </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="102">gatherings like parties or group meetings but 40% of the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="103">respondents washed their hand with soap and water </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="104">thoroughly and more frequently when they visit swine flu </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="105">infected areas while, 40% avoided close contact with the </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="106">people who appeared unwell. In another study 59.5% had </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="107">not cancelled or postponed any social event; 67.6% had not </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="108">7. Blendon RJ, Koonin LM, Benson JM. Public </Line>
<Line style="font-family:Calibri; font-size:9.96; color:#000000; line_num="109">response to community mitigation measures for </Line>
